writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose & Target Audience
- Purpose: Educate and inspire readers by giving them practical project ideas they can build very quickly using AI, showcasing concrete examples of what can be done in under an hour.
- Target Audience: Technical learners, AI beginners, aspiring solopreneurs, and developers looking to build their portfolio with quick, meaningful projects.

Step 2: Post Wireframe
[Engaging Hook]
[List of 5 projects, with a line of context about each for scannability]
[CTA: What short project would you add?]

Step 3: The Meat
- List the 5 projects with a one-liner explanation for each (why it’s useful / what it does).

Step 4: CTA
- “What quick AI project would you add to this list?”

Step 5A: Hook Directions
1. [Ultrashort challenge] “Can you build something meaningful with AI in just an hour?”
2. [List teaser] “5 AI projects you can finish before lunch”
3. [Results-driven] “I built these 5 AI tools in under an hour—here’s what they are”
4. [Beginner-friendly angle] “You don’t need weeks to build with AI. Try these 5 projects in an hour.”
5. [User-provided phrasing] “5 AI projects you can build in (less than) an hour”

Step 5B: Notes on each direction
1. [Ultrashort challenge] Stresses time constraint, makes it sound achievable.
2. [List teaser] Fun, light tone—good scannability, feels approachable.
3. [Results-driven] Implies these are possible and have been done.
4. [Beginner-friendly] Encourages those who hesitate due to complexity/time.
5. [User’s phrasing] Good for clarity, but may lack urgency.

Step 5C: Chosen Hook
Option 2: “5 AI projects you can finish before lunch” feels catchy, practical, and signals minimal time investment directly.

Step 6: Full Post Draft
5 AI projects you can finish before lunch

You don’t need weeks to make something useful with AI. Here are 5 practical projects you can build in under an hour:

• PDF Summarization Tool — Feed a PDF, get a summary. Useful for research papers or client docs.
• Clustering Customer Reviews — Group similar reviews together to see what people talk about most.
• Document QA Chatbot — Chat with your docs by asking natural language questions.
• YouTube Comment Sentiment Analysis — Analyze what viewers are feeling on any video.
• Gmail Inbox Categorization — Automatically label and sort incoming emails.

Each project is a simple way to practice applied ML, use real data, and solve a real problem quickly.

What quick AI project would you add to this list?

Step 7: Review for Style, Voice, and Flow
- No business clichés or idioms.
- Factual, practical, and educational.
- Good spacing, clear bullets, snappy explanations.
- Flow and tone match Shaw’s sample posts.
- CTA is practical and focused.

Step 8: Write the Final Post
final_post:
5 AI projects you can finish before lunch ☕️

You don’t need weeks to build with AI. Here are 5 useful projects you can put together in under an hour:

• PDF Summarization Tool — Feed in a PDF and get an instant summary. Great for research papers or client docs.
• Clustering Customer Reviews — Automatically group similar feedback to spot trends or common pain points.
• Document QA Chatbot — Turn a set of documents into a chatbot you can query in plain English.
• YouTube Comment Sentiment Analysis — Find out what viewers really think by analyzing comment sentiment.
• Gmail Inbox Categorization — Set up simple rules to auto-label and sort your emails.

Each of these is practical, uses real data, and gives you a finished project to show off fast.

What quick AI project would you add to this list?
